In India there is an enormous gap between healthcare supply and demand. What do you think are the major steps that can be taken by the government to improve patient care in the country?

                              Gone are the days where we call ourselves a developing country. yes, on the basis of percapita income we are already a developed country. But it is a known fact that we do not meet the required standards in the aspect of demographic indicators. This cannot just be attributed to the country's massive population or its diversity. We cannot deny the fact that life expectancy of humans in our country has been steadily increasing in the past few decades owing to the lion's share in the budget being allocated to the primary sector. But the toughest part revolves around the proper utilisation of those funds as per norms and regulations.

                              In the recent times, the provision of healthcare services is gaining momentum- thanks to the healthcare schemes being launched to extend medical services to the unprivileged and down-trodden people. The people being benefitted from these schemes are quite a good number. But this is not all. Statistics reveal that there are still many places in the country where the medical facilities are not reachable. Increasing populatioin on one hand and creeping corruption on the other hand are hindering the delivery of medical services throghout the country. The problem is with every person involved in the delivery chain, who either donot perform their part of task properly or restrain others from doing their work. This can be corrected if and only if an able and sincere supervision is brought into picture and also the wrong-doers need to be convicted.This may help in curbing the swindling of the public money to a great extent.

                            The unavailability of primary healthcare centres is generally witnessed in the tribal areas where the uneducated people are not trained for first aid also. At times of emergency they lose their precious lives falling victims to the government's negligence. The first and foremost step to be performed by the government is to spread general awareness among the uneducated people. The PHCs play a major role in delivering the healthcare services. Those personnel should be assigned the task of creating medical awareness in the remote locations. Live saving medicines should be made available at every PHC. Stringent rules need to be employed which ensure that every single pi allocated for a purpose is properly accounted for. All the vital information has to be communicated to the local public for the purpose of transparency.

                          India is not financially backward, it is operationally backward. When a day comes where keeping the laws is considered more important than making the laws, not only healthcare supply but every other aspect directed towards public interest and wellbeing will witness success.
